title: Panel TRANSFORMATIVE TOOLS, EMERGING CHALLENGES: EMPIRICAL AND PRACTICAL EXPERIENCES WITH LARGE LANGUAGE MODELS FOR TEXT CLASSIF - AoIR Selected Papers of Internet Research
snippet: Fabio Giglietto and colleagues presented a paper reflecting on their investigation of the role of social media in shaping exposure to political news during the 2018 and 2022 Italian elections, using large language models (LLMs) to address methodological challenges.
description: This paper presented at AoIR mentions Fabio Giglietto and his colleagues' research on using large language models to analyze social media's role in shaping exposure to political news during the 2018 and 2022 Italian elections.

title: Insights and Report from the Coordinated Sharing Behavior Detection Conference - Vera.ai
snippet: Fabio Giglietto and Giada Marino presented insights from the vera.ai Alerts project, which tracked and analyzed coordinated accounts on Facebook. Their research identified coordinated posts, links, and new coordinated accounts, with notable activity in large groups and networks.

title: Mis and Disinformation in Global Health Symposium - Media Ecosystems Analysis Group

title: White Paper: The State of Social Media Research APIs & Tool in the DSA Era
snippet: Fabio Giglietto co-authored a white paper with Massimo Terenzi on how the Digital Services Act (DSA) is transforming data access for platform research. The white paper explores the implementation of Article 40.12, which mandates Very Large Online Platforms (VLOPs) to provide access to “publicly available data.”
description: The white paper, co-authored by Fabio Giglietto, examines the impact of the Digital Services Act (DSA) on data access for platform research, specifically focusing on the implementation of Article 40.12 concerning publicly available data.

title: Fabio Giglietto's research works
snippet: Lists Fabio Giglietto's research publications, including a preprint on Meta's political content reduction policy and its impact on Italian parliamentarians' Facebook visibility. The study examines the effects of Meta's policy using a dataset of over 2.5 million Facebook posts and identifies breakpoints that reveal policy effects.
description: This ResearchGate page lists Fabio Giglietto's research publications, including a preprint about Meta's content policies' impact on Italian parliamentarians. It highlights his work on social media analysis and policy impacts.

title: Facebook, troppa visibilità a estremisti e complottisti: ecco come impatta Meta sulle elezioni
snippet: A study by Professor Fabio Giglietto analyzed over 2.5 million posts on the platform between 2021 and 2025 and found that Meta's algorithmic choices in distributing political content favored extremist and anti-European Union voices while penalizing institutional politics.
description: The press release discusses a study by Professor Fabio Giglietto analyzing over 2.5 million Facebook posts to determine Meta's impact on elections, specifically focusing on the amplification of extremist and anti-EU voices.

title: L'Europa assolda Urbino contro le fake-news - Il Resto del Carlino
snippet: This article reports on the European Union investing 7 million euros in the Vera.ai project, which aims to combat disinformation. A team coordinated by Fabio Giglietto, a professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino, will receive 400,000 euros as a partner in the project. Giglietto discusses the urgency of addressing disinformation to protect the democratic system and mentions the exploitation of uncertainty during the pandemic to spread skepticism and fear.
description: This article discusses the European Union's Vera.ai project aimed at combating disinformation, in which Fabio Giglietto, Professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino, is participating with his research team.

title: Secondo uno studio dell'università di Urbino l'algoritmo di Facebook ora punisce la politica ufficiale e premia gli estremisti antieuropei. Pd e FdI verso una legge bipartisan sulle piattaforme
snippet: A study by the University of Urbino, authored by Professor Fabio Giglietto, analyzes the effects of Meta's algorithmic choices on the distribution and visibility of political content on Facebook. The study highlights transparency deficits, noting that algorithmic suppression is less effective against extremists. The research analyzed over 2.5 million Facebook posts between 2021 and 2025.
description: This article on open.online discusses a study by Professor Fabio Giglietto from the University of Urbino that analyzes the impact of Facebook's algorithms on political content, specifically regarding disinformation and the visibility of extremist viewpoints.

title: SOS! Ora l'algoritmo punta sui complottisti: "Intervenire subito!"
snippet: This article refers to a research by the University of Urbino, led by Professor Fabio Giglietto, highlighting that the visibility of posts by Italian parliamentarians on Facebook has decreased significantly between 2021 and 2025, while 'extremist' accounts have increased their visibility. The article quotes Professor Giglietto describing these 'extremists' as Facebook pages and public figures characterized by anti-system narratives, criticism of mainstream media, and skepticism about vaccination policies.
description: This article on byoblu.com discusses research led by Professor Fabio Giglietto from the University of Urbino, focusing on the decreased visibility of Italian parliamentarians on Facebook compared to extremist accounts.

title: Più visibilità agli estremisti che ai parlamentari, l'impatto del “filtro” di Meta sulle elezioni
snippet: This article discusses a study titled “Meta's Political Content Reduction Policy and Italian Parliamentarians' Facebook Visibility” by Fabio Giglietto, a professor at the University of Urbino. The article mentions that the study found a significant decrease in the visibility of Italian parliamentarians' posts, while extremist accounts maintained or increased their visibility.

title: Algoritmi Meta, più spazio agli estremisti e meno alla politica ufficiale
snippet: A research study conducted by Fabio Giglietto of the University of Urbino, analyzing over 2.5 million Facebook posts between 2021 and 2025, found that posts from Italian parliamentarians and politicians experienced an average reach reduction of 72%. The study also indicated that extremist and anti-European accounts were the only ones able to increase their overall visibility during 2024. The study also highlights that Meta did not communicate the existence or effects of this policy on disinformation during elections in its mandatory Transparency Reports to the European Commission.
description: The article discusses a research study by Fabio Giglietto of the University of Urbino analyzing Facebook's algorithms and their impact on the visibility of political and extremist content in Italy.

title: MENO POLITICA SU META, ESTREMISTI IN VANTAGGIO - 9Colonne
snippet: A research study by Fabio Giglietto from the University of Urbino, analyzing over 2.5 million posts on 901 Facebook accounts from January 2021 to November 2025, reveals a decline in the visibility of institutional politics and an increase in the reach of 'extremist' content. The visibility of posts from parliamentarians and prominent politicians decreased by an average of 72%, while posts with 'extremist' content increased their reach by over 13%.
description: The article reports on a research study by Fabio Giglietto from the University of Urbino, which analyzes Facebook posts to show a decline in the visibility of political content and a rise in extremist content.

snippet: This article discusses a study published on January 7, 2026, by the University of Urbino, authored by Professor Fabio Giglietto, analyzing the effects of Meta's algorithmic choices on the distribution and visibility of political content on its platforms. The study highlights transparency deficits, noting that the algorithmic suppression appears less effective against extremist actors than against institutional politicians.
description: The article discusses a study by Professor Fabio Giglietto from the University of Urbino, analyzing the impact of Facebook's algorithm on political content and highlighting transparency issues related to extremist content.

title: Who is behind vera.ai? Meet the people and teams that make up the vera.ai project. #8 Team of University of Urbino Carlo Bo
snippet: This page introduces the team at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo working on the vera.ai project, led by Fabio Giglietto. It describes their roles and objectives within the project, which focuses on detecting potentially problematic content in near-real-time using a content-agnostic approach, specifically addressing coordinated sharing behavior.
description: This page introduces the team at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo working on the vera.ai project, led by Fabio Giglietto, focusing on detecting potentially problematic content and coordinated sharing behavior.

title: L'Università di Urbino in prima linea per la lotta alle fake news
snippet: Reports on Fabio Giglietto coordinating a team at the University of Urbino participating in the Vera.ai project, which aims to develop AI-based solutions to combat fake news. Mentions his research program Mapping Italian News (mine.uniurb.it).

title: Home | Professor of Internet Studies
snippet: This is a bio page for Fabio Giglietto, PhD, a Professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo. It highlights his research interests in disinformation, social media analysis, computational social science, and political communication. It mentions his work on coordinated link-sharing behavior during the Italian elections.

title: Detection and Characterization of Coordinated Online Behavior: A Survey - arXiv
snippet: This survey paper cites Fabio Giglietto's work on coordinated online behavior, specifically mentioning his 2023 paper with Marino, Mincigrucci, and Stanziano on detecting and monitoring coordinated social media accounts during the 2022 Italian election, as well as Giglietto et al. [2020a].
description: This survey paper cites Fabio Giglietto's research on coordinated online behavior, specifically referencing his 2023 paper on the Italian election and a 2020 paper. It demonstrates the influence of his work within the field of social media analysis.

title: 'Fake news' is the invention of a liar: How false information circulates within the hybrid news system - IRIS
snippet: This entry references Fabio Giglietto's work on 'fake news' and how false information circulates within the hybrid news system. Co-authors include Laura Iannelli, Augusto Valeriani, and Luca Rossi.
description: The entry references Fabio Giglietto's research on 'fake news' and its circulation within the hybrid news system, indicating a third-party mention of his academic work. The co-authors also suggest this is a legitimate research project.

title: Coordinated Link Sharing Behavior as a Signal to Surface Sources of Problematic Information on Facebook | Request PDF - ResearchGate
snippet: This ResearchGate entry discusses Fabio Giglietto's work (Giglietto et al. 2020) on coordinated link-sharing behavior (CLSB) as a signal to surface sources of problematic information on Facebook. It highlights how coordinated networks manipulate visibility and media narratives and how CLSB is associated with higher risks of encountering problematic news sources.
description: This ResearchGate entry references Fabio Giglietto's 2020 work on coordinated link-sharing behavior (CLSB) and its connection to the spread of problematic information on Facebook.

title: POLITICAL ADVERTISEMENT AND COORDINATED BEHAVIOR ON SOCIAL MEDIA IN THE LEAD-UP TO THE 2021 GERMAN FEDERAL ELECTIONS - Landesanstalt für Medien NRW
snippet: This study references Fabio Giglietto's research on Coordinated Link Sharing Behavior (CLSB) and coordinated networks on Facebook, specifically citing 'Giglietto, Righetti, Rossi, & Marino, 2020'. It discusses the use of CLSB to spread anti-establishment narratives and disinformation during elections.
description: This study on political advertisement and coordinated behavior during the 2021 German Federal Elections references Fabio Giglietto's research on Coordinated Link Sharing Behavior (CLSB) and its use in spreading disinformation.

title: Fabio Giglietto
snippet: Fabio Giglietto, PhD, is a distinguished Professor of Internet Studies at the Department of Communication Sciences, Humanities, and International Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo. His research focuses on social media analysis, computational social science, and the detection and analysis of disinformation campaigns, particularly in the context of political communication.
description: The content explicitly mentions Fabio Giglietto as a Professor of Internet Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo, detailing his research focus on social media analysis, computational social science, and disinformation campaigns, aligning with his expertise.

title: Meet the speakers! - EUDTP 2025 - EuroTech Universities Alliance
snippet: Fabio Giglietto is a speaker at the EU Digital Technologies and Policies (EUDTP) conference in Brussels on May 14 and 15, 2025. He will be discussing implementation challenges and opportunities under the Digital Services Act (DSA).

title: Conference Schedule - International Conference on Social Media & Society

title: PROMPT_whitepaper_The State of Social Media Research APIs & Tools in the Digital Service Act Era - Zenodo
snippet: Fabio Giglietto, along with Massimo Terenzi, authored a white paper from the University of Urbino Carlo Bo, analyzing how the European Union’s Digital Services Act (DSA) is transforming data access for platform research. It draws on existing literature and testing of research APIs/tools from platforms like Meta, YouTube, and TikTok. The paper focuses on Article 40.12, which mandates access to publicly available data, and examines how Very Large Online Platforms (VLOPs) are implementing these requirements, identifying gaps, challenges, and potential solutions. Published: 2024-12-19.
description: Fabio Giglietto co-authored a white paper from the University of Urbino Carlo Bo analyzing the impact of the Digital Services Act (DSA) on data access for platform research, focusing on how VLOPs are implementing Article 40.12 regarding publicly available data.

title: Professor of Internet Studies
snippet: Fabio Giglietto is a Professor of Internet Studies at the Department of Communication Sciences, Humanities, and International Studies at the University of Urbino Carlo Bo. His research focuses on the relationships between social systems, media, and digital technologies, with recent projects focusing on social media analysis, computational social science, and the detection and analysis of disinformation campaigns.
